comments.commentBody: I don't buy Ruth Madoff's denial for one second.  There is no way that she did not know. Since his two sons worked in the business, the only way that they did not know is if they were complete idiots. Nothing was real; could they have really believed 100% was?
I change the channel every time I see one of their faces on the screen.

If Andrew wants sympathy, he should give back his $60 million.  I don't believe for a second that he earned $60 million from trading.  A top trader gets 15% of money he earned, which would mean that Andrew made $400 million in trading.  Andrew, you know that's ill-gotten gains, give back the money to the victims!

The interviews had the stink of "woe is me" ahead of all the others who were deceived. If investors did not do due diligence, and the ROI blinded them, they have some responsibility, but the SEC even more so because they were told it was a ponzi scheme years ago, and ignored the facts. Speaking of, did Andrew and Mark ever wonder how the returns on Dad's "investments" stayed steady and strong? Hawking a book to soothe their souls tells more about the Madoffs and do we really care?

Since no one will ever know the real truth.  Its safe to say that everyone will get theirs at the end. Life goes on, and rest assure there will be many other scams to be reported.  Human greed and ignorance has not limits.

In this telling story, the age-old divide of rulers and ruled is detailed, as well as a stunningly flagrant object lesson in moral obtuseness.

Steal money from members of the leadership class, you are a monster, hideously duplicitous, a traitor to your class, unforgivably incomprehensible. Even after you are jailed and your son kills himself, your former friends are icy cold.

Quite a lesson. Our leadership is a cold group. Don't mess with them. They'll shut you out, just like the rest of the country--the remaining 99.09.

By contrast, if you happened to be a member of a class of financiers who, together with government regulators and policy makers, precipitate a colossal mortgage-based debacle, throwing Americans, including children, on the streets, stalling the economy, draining the ordinary person's wealth, not a single responsible person is singled out for public obloquy. No investigations ensue.

Same old story, same old song and dance: What is bad for the goose (and fodder for maudlin pity) is reason for the gander to work so much harder.

It's interesting how society is all worked up over the Madoffs. The thing about the crime is that all the damages are recoverable: the money was not lost it was just transferred to other person or charitable institutions. The victims are not worth as much as they thought, but the rest of america is not either.
There are many other investments that had worse effect on investors than Madoff during the period: Greek debt, internet companies, certain hedge funds, mortgage backed securities. For these investments, a single perpetrator is difficult to identify. But they could all be characterized as worse than Ponzi schemes. Viewing the crime from this larger lens, Madoff, was a criminal, but not clever or big enough. His flaw was a lack of ingenuity and big-picture thinking. He began his scheme out of cowardliness rather than boldness, and with the small notion of defrauding over time instead of using one vehicle to pin his hopium dreams on. He could have chosen an investment vehicle which had a 90% rate of failure over a few years rather than a 100% rate of failure over time. That's the odd part. He must have seen no end to the corruption.
While there are others that are more deserving of tears than Ruth and Andrew.  I do feel that they do not deserve the same amount of guilt as Madoff.  Let's say I have mixed feelings on the matter.

Why does everyone refer to the Madoff brokerage business as "legitimate"?  Was not the basis of it the payment for order flow model?  This was commonly known as "payola" in the music industry.  The beneficiaries were Madoff and the well known brokerage firms that sold their customers' orders to Madoff to pick-off.  The victims were the retail customers of these skimmers and coin shavers.  The big question that Henriques never faces is, "Who was Madoff's protector at the SEC?"

It is very easy to dismiss all of this, to say "oh boo hoo," even to the investors who lost money. But I feel sorry for all of the Madoffs, including Bernie. The scale and reach of this disaster pretty clearly demonstrate that he didn't know what he was doing, that it was all out of control. To imagine it as a malicious act is ridiculous. He is an incompetent fool, and that's sad.

She stayed with him, even through scandal and suspected infidelity, as long as there was still money. She changed her phone number and blew him off when he needed her most. Her marriage vows must have read, "For better or worse, as long as he still has money." He's a despicable character, but who walks out on their spouse at his darkest hour? She enjoyed the homes, the cars, the vacations, the $800 shoes, but only grew a conscious when the lifestyle went away! She could at least honor her marriage vows when it all went bad. I have no respect for her. None, whatsoever.
Three cheers to Harry Markopolos, the only person that seems to have tried to stop what was going on for years.
Her oldest son committed suicide as a result of the pressure and shame.  There's no greater punishment for a mother.  Let her live what remains of her life in peace.
I think that Mrs. Maddoff would do well to spend her time helping people less fortunate that she has been the rest of her life. Guilty or not, it would do her a world of good.

The best thing they could do for the victims is refrain from making a spectacle of themselves in an effort to gain sympathy.  It isn't dignified and certainly cannot fix the past.  Too late for that, apparently.

Andrew and Peter and Stephanie and Ruth Madoff all continue to lead lives of luxury on the money their father illegally cheated people of.  I will have sympathy for them when they make 100% restitution.  Not until then.

As a victim of the Madoff fraud, it gives me pain every time the Media gives coverage to the family of the perpetrators. I find it hard to believe that the son's knew nothing of the fraud, they had millions dollars invested in the Ponzi scheme they received statements showing outsized returns. Did they not notice that their were no traders on the 19 floor capable of managing billions of dollars of trades. That when their father was on extended vacation the portfolio still turned over like clockwork. Working on wall st seeing their statements did they not ever question their dad on how always was able to beat the market.
People see what they want to see, his kids & wife cared not to notice what should have been obvious to anyone with such up close access.

I have watched 60 minutes, I have read these comments and still do not have an ounce of sympathy for Ruth nor her son.  Of course, he needs to return the money Bernie gave him during the Ponzi scheme from which he profited.  Both need to start over like most of us. She on Bernie's Social Security as she choose not to work; the son on nothing but the proceeds of his wife's book.  He is young

I feel compassion for the innocent family members. I watched Mark's wife on 20/20 and I believe her when she said her husband did not know. She has a book out as well. The sons turned their father in. Had they been involved, they would never have done that.
Bernie Madoff is a despicable human being for what he did to the victims whose money was invested in his fraudulent company and for what he did to his wife and his children. Even the grandchildren are being sued. I understand why his surviving son hates him and his daughter in law as well. Disgraceful.

Are these 60 minute interview and book writing, all staged by PR adviser to do to defend against  pending multiple civil suits and free advertisement for book selling even though 60 minutes claimed Madoffs will not get benefits from it? The family must have lived in i-cloud to be clueless. Who is kidding who? It is sad for the 60 minutes news media to be a messenger for Madoff family as innocent victims. By the way, victim trust lawyers are about to collect billions dollar for their service as their suit surpass the entire estimated loss from Madoff's scheme and a lot more, and who is paying this?

The mother and sons, one son now deceased, lived off the fat of the land on this one with yachts, homes, jewels et al. Mother and remaining son should not make money off a book detailing their misfortunes.  That's what shrinks are for! The SEC should have found the money and made good, as much as possible, to the individuals and non-profit organizations that were swindled by Bernie Madoff and his accomplices.

I don't know what Ruth or the sons knew - it's hard to believe that no one knew anything, but millions of people think Fox News tells them the truth. I'm not in a position to judge Ruth and co.'s knowledge or innocence.  But I can despise them for being completely emotionally tone deaf.  People are suffering, unemployment is through the roof, and we're all being held hostage by Republicans.  Yet Ruth, the son, and the fiance are flooding the media asking us to feel sorry for them because public opinion hurt their feelings.  Even better, the fiance (who will be keeping all the book money) is making this appeal in $800 shoes.  Note to PR flack: those red soles are a dead giveaway. If she has to wear them, take a sharpie to the soles.
I think a lot of the people clamoring for her blood got exactly what they deserved. If you want unsympathetic characters, look no further than the "cry me a river" brigade.

Paul in NJ, so my father commits a crime and I should forfeit all of my assets? Not saying the sons didn't know, but you seem quick to accuse them! I feel the man was a snake and his family was in the dark of it all, I don't feel sorry for them, but also don't feel they are to blame.
What happened to the Times editorial staff that I have to be confronted with stories about Ruth Madoff on the front page of the website twice in a week?
